dinosaurs.name: Postosuchus
dinosaurs.clasification: Rauisuchian (Archosaur, estrechamente relacionado con los crocodylomorfos)
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnívoro
dinosaurs.speed: ~40 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Cráneo similar al de un cocodrilo, extremidades robustas y postura semi-erguida
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Dientes afilados, gran fuerza de mordida, depredador de emboscada
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: USA (Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, North Carolina)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Habitualmente solitario
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Más emparentado con los cocodrilos que con los dinosaurios

dinosaurs.name: Eoraptor
dinosaurs.clasification: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Herrerasauridae (Considerado a veces un terópodo primitivo)
dinosaurs.diet_type: Omnívoro (comía animales pequeños, insectos, y plantas)
dinosaurs.speed: Se estima que era un corredor veloz, posiblemente alcanzando hasta 40 km/h (25 mph)
dinosaurs.special_features: Pequeño, ligero y ágil, con garras afiladas y una mordida rápida
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Dientes afilados para desgarrar carne, y garras en sus manos para atrapar a sus presas
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: Argentina, en la Formación Ischigualasto (Valle de la Luna)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Probablemente solitario o parte de pequeños grupos
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Considerado uno de los dinosaurios más primitivos, cercano al ancestro común de terópodos y saurópodos

dinosaurs.name: Herrerasaurus
dinosaurs.clasification: Terópodo primitivo (o saurischio basal, en debate)
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnívoro
dinosaurs.special_features: Patas largas y poderosas; manos prensiles; dientes aserrados
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Garras afiladas, mordida poderosa y velocidad para acechar
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: Argentina, en la Formación Ischigualasto (Valle de la Luna)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Probablemente solitario o parte de pequeños grupos
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Uno de los primeros dinosaurios, potencialmente ancestral de los terópodos posteriores

dinosaurs.name: Shuvosaurus
dinosaurs.clasification: Archosauria, Poposauroidea (originalmente cosiderado un ornitomímido, posteriormente identificado un reptil, más emparentado con los cocodrilos)
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbívoro
dinosaurs.speed: Considerado un veloz corredor bípedo
dinosaurs.special_features: Pico desdentado, piernas largas, cuerpo ligero y ágil
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: La velocidad y la agilidad fueron probablemente sus principales mecanismos de defensa
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Desconocido, posiblemente era solitario o vivía en pequeños grupos
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Inicialmente confundido con un dinosaurio terópodo, luego se identificó como miembro de la línea Crocodilia, emparentado con otros poposauroideos

dinosaurs.name: Fukuiraptor
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnívoro (probablemente se alimentaba de animales de tamaño pequeño a mediano)
dinosaurs.speed: Considerado un veloz y ágil depredador
dinosaurs.special_features: Garras grandes en las manos, ligeramente diseñadas para mayor agilidad
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Usaba sus garras afiladas y dientes para atrapar y matar a sus presas
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Desconocido, posiblemente era un cazador solitario
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Miembro del grupo Megaraptora, posiblemente emparentado con alosauroideos o tiranosauroideos.

dinosaurs.name: Chindesaurus
dinosaurs.clasification: Dinosauria, Saurischia, Herrerasauridae (o posiblemente un Terópodo basal)
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnívoro (probablemente se alimentaba de pequeños animales e insectos)
dinosaurs.speed: considerado un veloz corredor, usaba sus piernas largas para mayor agilidad
dinosaurs.special_features: Cuerpo esbelto, dientes afilados
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Usaba sus dientes afilados y garras para atrapar y matar su presa
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely solitary or lived in small hunting groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Considered a primitive saurischian dinosaur, possibly related to early theropods or herrerasaurids

dinosaurs.name: Coelophysis
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous
dinosaurs.speed: Likely a fast and agile runner, estimated at 40–50 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Lightweight body, long tail for balance, sharp teeth for catching prey
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Used its speed to hunt and escape predators, had sharp teeth and claws for attacking prey
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: United States (New Mexico, Arizona), possibly Zimbabwe and South Africa
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Evidence suggests it lived in groups, possibly for hunting or protection
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: An early theropod, related to later larger theropods like Dilophosaurus and Allosaurus

dinosaurs.name: Plateosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivorous (fed on ferns, cycads, and other prehistoric plants)
dinosaurs.speed: Could walk on both two and four legs, likely reaching speeds of 5–10 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Long neck, strong hind legs, grasping hands with large claws for feeding
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Could use its large size to intimidate predators; strong claws might have been used for defense
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Evidence suggests it may have lived in groups, but some studies indicate solitary behavior
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: An early sauropodomorph, related to later giant sauropods like Brachiosaurus and Apatosaurus

dinosaurs.name: Rauisuchus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (likely preyed on large herbivorous reptiles and early dinosaurs)
dinosaurs.speed: Likely a fast runner, aided by strong hind legs
dinosaurs.special_features: Large skull with powerful jaws, serrated teeth for tearing flesh, upright posture
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Used its strong bite and sharp teeth to subdue prey, possibly an ambush predator
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely a solitary hunter
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Rauisuchidae, related to other Triassic predators like Postosuchus and distant relatives of modern crocodilians

dinosaurs.name: Dilophosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~35-40 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Twin crests on the skull, long slender body
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Sharp teeth, claws, speed for ambush hunting
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Possibly solitary or in small hunting groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Early theropod, related to later large carnivores like Allosaurus

dinosaurs.name: Compsognathus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivore (likely insectivore and small vertebrates)
dinosaurs.speed: ~64 km/h, one of the fastest dinosaurs
dinosaurs.special_features: Small, lightweight body; long tail for balance
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Speed and agility; sharp teeth for catching small prey
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Possibly solitary or in small groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to later theropods, including Tyrannosaurus rex

dinosaurs.name: Cryolophosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (likely preyed on smaller dinosaurs and other prehistoric animals)
dinosaurs.speed: Likely a fast and agile runner
dinosaurs.special_features: Distinctive crest on its skull, possibly used for display or dominance behavior
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Sharp teeth and claws for hunting, likely used speed and ambush tactics
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Unclear, but may have been solitary or lived in small groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: An early theropod, possibly related to Dilophosaurus and other primitive Jurassic carnivores

dinosaurs.name: Allosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~30-40 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Large skull with serrated teeth, strong legs, and three-fingered claws
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Powerful bite, sharp claws, ambush predator tactics
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: USA (Morrison Formation), Portugal, and possibly Tanzania
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Evidence suggests possible pack hunting, but debated
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to later theropods like Tyrannosaurus rex

dinosaurs.name: Apatosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~20-30 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Long neck, whip-like tail, massive body structure
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Large size as deterrent; potential use of tail as a whip for defense
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely lived in herds
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to other sauropods like Brontosaurus and Diplodocus

dinosaurs.name: Camarasaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~10-15 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Shorter neck than some sauropods, large spoon-shaped teeth for eating tough vegetation
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Large size as primary deterrent; tail could be used for defense
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely lived in herds or family groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to Brachiosaurus and other macronarian sauropods

dinosaurs.name: Brachiosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~10-15 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Long neck, front legs longer than hind legs (giving it a giraffe-like posture), large nostrils on top of the head
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Enormous size as a deterrent; possible tail or foot stomping for defense
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: USA (Morrison Formation), possible related species in Africa (Giraffatitan)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely lived in herds or family groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to other macronarian sauropods like Camarasaurus and Giraffatitan

dinosaurs.name: Diplodocus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~8-15 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Extremely long neck and tail, whip-like tail, small head with peg-like teeth
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Large size as a deterrent; possible use of tail as a whip for defense
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely lived in herds
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to Apatosaurus and Barosaurus

dinosaurs.name: Stegosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbívoro
dinosaurs.speed: Estimada en ~6-9 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Placas óseas en la espalda y cuatro púas en la cola (thagomizer)
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Cola con púas utilizada como arma contra depredadores
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Posiblemente vivía en pequeños grupos
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Relacionado con otros estegosaurios como Kentrosaurus

dinosaurs.name: Pachycephalosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivorous (likely ate leaves, fruits, and seeds)
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated to be a moderate runner, possibly reaching up to 24 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Thick, domed skull up to 25 cm (10 inches) thick, small leaf-shaped teeth, bipedal stance
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Possibly used its thick skull for headbutting, either in combat with rivals or for defense
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: United States, particularly in Montana, South Dakota, and Wyoming
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Uncertain, but may have lived in small groups or been solitary
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Pachycephalosauridae, closely related to other dome-headed dinosaurs like Stygimoloch and Dracorex

dinosaurs.name: Microceratus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivorous (likely fed on low-growing plants like ferns and cycads)
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated to be a fast and agile runner
dinosaurs.special_features: Small size, lightweight body, beaked mouth for cropping vegetation, likely lacked large horns
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Relied on speed and agility to escape predators
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: Mongolia, particularly in the Gobi Desert
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Possibly lived in small groups or herds
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: One of the earliest known ceratopsians, related to later, larger species like Protoceratops and Triceratops

dinosaurs.name: Gallimimus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Omnivorous (likely ate plants, small animals, insects, and possibly eggs)
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated to reach speeds of up to 60 km/h (37 mph), making it one of the fastest dinosaurs
dinosaurs.special_features: Long legs built for running, toothless beak, long neck, and large eyes
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Relied on speed and agility to escape predators
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: Mongolia, particularly in the Nemegt Formation
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Possibly lived in groups or flocks
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Ornithomimidae, related to other "ostrich-like" dinosaurs like Struthiomimus and Ornithomimus

dinosaurs.name: Spinosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (primarily piscivorous, feeding on fish, but possibly scavenged or hunted small prey)
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated to be a slow land mover but well-adapted for swimming
dinosaurs.special_features: Large sail-like structure on its back, elongated crocodile-like skull, conical teeth designed for gripping fish, semi-aquatic adaptations
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Strong jaws and claws for catching prey, likely an ambush predator in water
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: North Africa, including Egypt and Morocco
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Uncertain, but may have been solitary or semi-social
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Spinosauridae, closely related to Baryonyx and Suchomimus

dinosaurs.name: Baryonyx
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (primarily piscivorous, but also scavenged or hunted small prey)
dinosaurs.speed: Moderate speed on land, possibly adept at swimming
dinosaurs.special_features: Long, crocodile-like snout with conical teeth, large claws (especially a 31 cm thumb claw), semi-aquatic adaptations
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Strong jaws for catching fish, sharp claws for slashing or gripping prey
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely solitary or semi-social
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Spinosauridae, closely related to Spinosaurus and Suchomimus

dinosaurs.name: Irritator
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (primarily piscivorous but may have hunted small prey)
dinosaurs.speed: Moderate speed on land, likely a capable swimmer
dinosaurs.special_features: Elongated, crocodile-like snout with conical teeth, well-adapted for catching fish, relatively small crest on the head
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Strong jaws and sharp teeth for gripping slippery prey
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: Brazil, particularly in the Santana Formation
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Uncertain, but likely solitary or semi-social
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Spinosauridae, closely related to Spinosaurus, Baryonyx, and Suchomimus

dinosaurs.name: Triceratops
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivore
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated ~25 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Large frill, three facial horns
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Horns for defense, powerful build
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Likely herding behavior
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: Related to modern birds (distantly)

dinosaurs.name: Ankylosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Herbivorous (fed on low-growing plants like ferns, cycads, and conifers)
dinosaurs.speed: Slow-moving, estimated at around 10 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Heavily armored body covered in bony plates (osteoderms), low and wide stance, small leaf-shaped teeth
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: Large, powerful club-like tail used to defend against predators
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: North America, particularly in Montana, Wyoming, and Alberta (Canada)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Uncertain, but may have lived alone or in small groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Ankylosauridae, closely related to Euoplocephalus and other armored dinosaurs

dinosaurs.name: Tyrannosaurus
dinosaurs.diet_type: Carnivorous (apex predator, hunted large herbivores like Triceratops and Edmontosaurus, but may have also scavenged)
dinosaurs.speed: Estimated to reach speeds of 20 to 30 km/h
dinosaurs.special_features: Massive skull (up to 1.5 meters long), powerful bite force (over 35,000 Newtons), forward-facing eyes for depth perception, small but strong arms with two claws
dinosaurs.defense_attack_mechanism: One of the strongest bite forces of any land animal, capable of crushing bone; strong legs for short bursts of speed
dinosaurs.fossils_found_in: North America, particularly in Montana, South Dakota, Wyoming, and Alberta (Canada)
dinosaurs.social_behaviour: Debated, but may have been solitary or lived in small groups
dinosaurs.evolutionary_relationship: A member of Tyrannosauridae, closely related to Albertosaurus and Gorgosaurus
